title: Solomon's Charge and Kingdom Established
shortSummary: This chapter records the final instructions of King David to Solomon, emphasizing obedience to God's law and wise leadership. It also details Solomon's consolidation of power through the execution of his rivals and the establishment of his reign, highlighting the fulfillment of God's promises to David.
timeline: c. 970 BC - Transition from King David to King Solomon in Israel

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The aging king of Israel who charges Solomon to be strong, obedient to God, and to establish his kingdom righteously before his death.

keyCharacters.name: Solomon
keyCharacters.description: David’s son and successor, who receives his father’s charge and takes decisive actions to secure his throne and fulfill God's promises.

keyCharacters.name: Adonijah
keyCharacters.description: David’s son who previously attempted to claim the throne, ultimately requesting Abishag as a wife, which leads to his execution by Solomon.

keyCharacters.name: Joab
keyCharacters.description: David’s military commander known for violent acts, whose death is ordered by Solomon as part of securing his reign.

keyCharacters.name: Abiathar
keyCharacters.description: A priest who supported Adonijah and is removed from his priestly office by Solomon, fulfilling a prophecy concerning the house of Eli.

definitions.definition: An old or gray head, symbolizing old age and often respect; here it refers to the aged Joab.
God’s commandments and statutes that leaders are to obey and uphold for blessing and prosperity.
The projecting corners of the altar in the tabernacle where a person could seek asylum or protection.
To make a solemn oath invoking God as a witness to the truth or binding nature of a promise.

outline.heading: David’s Final Charge to Solomon
outline.description: David instructs Solomon to be strong, walk in God’s statutes, and deal wisely with his enemies, emphasizing obedience to the LORD for the prosperity and stability of his reign.

outline.heading: David’s Death and Solomon’s Ascension
outline.description: David dies and is buried, and Solomon officially takes the throne, with his kingdom firmly established.

outline.heading: Adonijah’s Request and Downfall
outline.description: Adonijah requests Abishag as a wife, which Solomon interprets as a political threat, leading to Adonijah’s execution to secure Solomon’s kingship.

outline.heading: Removal of Abiathar and Execution of Joab
outline.description: Solomon removes Abiathar from the priesthood and orders the death of Joab, fulfilling God’s word and removing threats to his reign.

outline.heading: Shimei’s Confinement and Death
outline.description: Solomon confines Shimei under threat of death for past offenses against David; when Shimei violates this, Solomon orders his execution, securing peace for his kingdom.

application: Obey God’s commands faithfully as the foundation for strong and prosperous leadership in your life.
Exercise wisdom and discernment in dealing with conflicts and opposition, trusting God’s guidance.
Honor the legacy and instructions of godly leaders who have gone before you.
Recognize that God’s promises are fulfilled through obedience and righteous action, encouraging steadfast faith.

keyVerses.text: And keep the charge of the LORD thy God, to walk in his ways, to keep his statutes, and his commandments, and his judgments, and his testimonies, as it is written in the law of Moses, that thou mayest prosper in all that thou doest, and whithersoever thou turnest thyself:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the central importance of obedience to God's law as the key to Solomon’s success and blessing.

keyVerses.text: That the LORD may continue his word which he spake concerning me, saying, If thy children take heed to their way, to walk before me in truth with all their heart and with all their soul, there shall not fail thee (said he) a man on the throne of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms God’s covenant promise to David that his descendants will rule Israel if they remain faithful.

keyVerses.text: So the king commanded Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; which went out, and fell upon him, that he died. And the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the decisive action Solomon takes to secure his kingdom and fulfill God’s plan for his reign.
